metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network: automatic weather station of Huazhaizi desert steppe station, 2022
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Huazhaizi desert steppe station from January 1 to December 31, 2022. The site (100.3201°E, 38.7659°N) was located on a desert steppe surface in the Huazhaizi, which is near Zhangye city, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1731 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (HMP45AC; 5 and 10 m, north), wind speed and direction profile (windsonic; 5 and 10 m, north), air pressure (CS100; 2 m), rain gauge (TE525M; 10 m), four-component radiometer (CNR1; 6 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (SI-111; 6 m, south, vertically downward), soil heat flux (HFP01; 3 duplicates, -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (109ss-L; 0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, -1.0 m), soil moisture profile (ML3; -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, -1.0 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_5 m and Ta_10 m; RH_5 m and RH_10 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_5 m and Ws_10 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_5 m and WD_10 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_60 cm, Ts_100 cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_60 cm, Ms_100 cm) (%).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2022-6-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What are oasis–desert systems in the context of arid and semi-arid regions?
Definition.Answer: An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that supports both ecological environments and economic development. Oasis–desert systems play a crucial role in maintaining stable ecological environments and agricultural productivity, especially in regions such as western China.

Definition.Question: What is the function of an eddy covariance system in data collection methods?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system is used for acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data, which includes measurements of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes. This system is crucial for understanding the exchange processes in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Interpretation.Question: What potential methodologies can be inferred for ensuring the accuracy and reliability of meteorological data collected in arid and semiarid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: To ensure accuracy and reliability, methodologies such as installing sensors at various heights and orientations, using protective measures like waterproof boxes for sensitive equipment, conducting regular data quality checks, removing duplicate entries, and filtering out values that exceed physical or instrumental limits are employed. Standardized formats for recording date and time also help maintain data consistency.

Interpretation.Question: How can long-term observational data contribute to understanding the interactions between oasis and desert systems in terms of energy and water vapor exchange?
Interpretation.Answer: Long-term observational data can provide insights into the quantitative characteristics of energy and water vapor exchange, which are crucial for understanding oasis–desert interactions. Such data are essential for achieving sustainable development goals, maintaining ecological stability, and supporting socio-economic development in these regions.

Interpretation.Question: What are the inferred challenges of collecting and processing data in the oasis–desert ecosystems, and what solutions might be implemented to overcome these challenges?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include ecological degradation, such as drying rivers and increased desertification. Solutions might involve establishing multiple observation stations to capture diverse data, using advanced instruments like eddy covariance systems, and implementing rigorous data processing and quality control procedures to ensure accurate and usable data outputs.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the challenges in maintaining long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing ecological environment degradation, which includes the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent occurrences of dust storms. These environmental crises, especially prevalent in inland river basins along the Silk Road, contribute significantly to the challenges in maintaining long-term observations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems for sustainable oasis development?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems is critical because oases are unique ecological landscapes in arid and semi-arid areas that support more than 90% of the population in these regions, despite comprising less than 10% of the total area. They play a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity, which are essential for the economic and ecological security in western China.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period for collecting hydrometeorological data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period for collecting hydrometeorological data can result in high-resolution temporal datasets that are crucial for understanding detailed energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes in oasis–desert ecosystems. These datasets can provide insights into the interactions between oasis and desert systems, which are essential for maintaining ecological stability and supporting sustainable development.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the presence of long-term observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems impact the understanding of ecological stability in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Long-term observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems can significantly enhance the understanding of ecological stability in arid regions by providing comprehensive data on energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes. This information is vital for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and assessing the balance required for sustainable oasis development, particularly in the context of carbon peaking and neutrality goals.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications for data accuracy and reliability when employing eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for measuring turbulent flux data in oasis–desert areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for measuring turbulent flux data can lead to high accuracy and reliability in capturing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes in oasis–desert areas. This approach allows for detailed and precise measurements that are critical for understanding the dynamics of oasis–desert ecosystems and their influence on the carbon balance and ecological security of arid regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of collecting long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended outcomes are to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, support ecological security, and promote sustainable development in these areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems in arid and semiarid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Maintaining this balance is crucial to achieve sustainable oasis development, protect ecological stability, and support socioeconomic development by understanding the interactions in oasis–desert systems and addressing environmental degradation challenges such as land desertification and dust storms.

Goal Orientation.Question: What drives the need for a comprehensive suite of observational datasets in oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The need is driven by the requirement to quantitatively understand energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, recognize oasis–desert interactions, and address ecological crises in arid and semiarid regions, particularly in areas affected by drying up of water bodies and land degradation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedures to ensure data quality and accuracy in meteorological data collection at the 黑河流域地表过程综合观测网?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedures include ensuring 144 data entries per day (every 10 minutes), marking missing data with -6999, removing duplicate records, deleting values that exceed physical significance or instrument range, marking questionable data with red text, and standardizing date and time formats in a single column.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the installation of sensors and instruments managed to capture diverse meteorological and soil parameters in arid regions like the 黑河流域?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Instruments are strategically placed at specific heights and orientations: air temperature and humidity sensors at 5m and 10m facing north, barometers in waterproof boxes, rain gauges at 10m, wind sensors at 5m and 10m facing north, radiation instruments at 6m facing south, infrared thermometers at 6m facing south with downward probes, and soil sensors at various depths and distances from the meteorological tower.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems to support sustainable development and ecological security?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A comprehensive understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems is emphasized, supported by long-term observations and quantitative analysis. This involves maintaining observational networks, analyzing interactions, and using datasets that include energy, water vapor, carbon fluxes, and hydrometeorological data.

Enablement.Question: What data processing techniques enable the effective quality control of meteorological observations in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedures include ensuring complete daily data collection, removing duplicate records, and deleting data that exceed physical or instrument limits, as well as marking questionable data for further review.

Enablement.Question: How does the use of automatic weather stations enable the collection of comprehensive hydrometeorological datasets in oasis-desert systems?
Enablement.Answer: Automatic weather stations enable the collection of comprehensive datasets by measuring various parameters such as radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture with a 10-minute average period.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in ensuring the quality and completeness of continuous meteorological data in arid and semiarid regions?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face ecological challenges such as river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, and land desertification, which can impact the consistent collection of meteorological data. Additionally, data quality control involves removing erroneous values and ensuring consistent recording formats, which can be affected by environmental factors and technical limitations.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of the data collection methods employed for monitoring meteorological variables in arid and semiarid oasis–desert systems?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection methods employed, which include the use of automatic weather stations with 10-minute average periods and eddy covariance systems, seem effective for capturing detailed hydrometeorological data, such as radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles. These methods allow for comprehensive long-term observations that are critical for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how comprehensive is the current dataset in capturing the necessary parameters for understanding oasis–desert interactions, and what additional data could enhance its scope?
Judgmental.Answer: The current dataset is quite comprehensive as it includes energy, water vapor, carbon fluxes, hydrometeorological data, and soil and vegetation parameters, which are crucial for understanding oasis–desert interactions. However, incorporating additional data on long-term climate trends and human-induced changes could further enhance its scope and provide deeper insights into the ecological and socioeconomic dynamics of these regions.

Assertion.Question: I'm not clear on how challenges like ecological degradation in arid regions are addressed through these observational datasets.
Assertion.Answer: The observational datasets provide long-term data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, which are crucial for understanding and addressing ecological degradation issues such as drying rivers, vegetation degradation, and desertification.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how these datasets contribute to understanding the interactions between oasis and desert systems.
Assertion.Answer: The datasets include comprehensive observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, which are essential for recognizing interactions between oasis and desert systems and supporting ecological and socioeconomic stability.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the methods used for data collection in arid and semiarid regions, specifically focusing on the instrumentation and parameters observed.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods involve using automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period to observe parameters like radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. Instruments such as eddy covariance systems and scintillometers are used to acquire turbulent flux data, while other sensors measure air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, wind direction, soil moisture, and soil temperature at various depths.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the challenges faced in collecting and processing data from oasis–desert systems in arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting and processing data from oasis–desert systems include ecological environment degradation such as drying rivers and lakes, natural vegetation degradation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. Data quality control measures are essential to ensure accuracy, requiring the exclusion of erroneous values, handling of missing data, and removal of duplicates. Additionally, maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems is critical for sustainable development.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss how datasets related to energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas are structured and shared for research purposes.
Request/Directive.Answer: Datasets related to energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas include observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, along with hydrometeorological data, vegetation, and soil parameters. These datasets are structured to include long-term data from land surface flux and meteorological stations, ensuring comprehensive coverage. The data are archived and shared freely through platforms like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center, supporting ongoing research and data accessibility.
